The Safe Drinking Water Act allows for mandatory assessment and consolidation of public water systems that repeatedly fail to comply with national drinking water regulations. The Safe Drinking Water Act allows for mandatory consolidation or transfer of ownership of public water systems to improve compliance with national primary drinking water regulations. The Safe Drinking Water Act mandates consolidation or transfer of ownership for public water systems that have completed assessments but failed to comply with national regulations, if feasible. The Administrator must establish regulations within 2 years of enactment. The Safe Drinking Water Act requires consolidation or transfer of ownership for non-compliant public water systems. Financial assistance is available for systems undergoing consolidation or transfer. Owners must identify liabilities and available funds in their consolidation plan. Public water systems undergoing consolidation must identify funds available to satisfy liabilities in their plan. Once consolidation is completed, the system will not be liable for damages from violations identified in the plan, except to the extent that funds are available to cover the liability. Public water systems undergoing consolidation must assess options for consolidation or transfer of ownership in accordance with regulations. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to include procedures for this requirement. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to remove certain paragraphs.
